newsitem.title: USA: Advanced Micro to unveil K6 chip, take on Intel.
newsitem.headline: Advanced Micro to unveil K6 chip, take on Intel.

text.p: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. on Wednesday will unveil its K6 microprocessor, a long-awaited computer chip that could be a formidible rival to chips from industry giant Intel Corp.
The K6 is the most important product launch for AMD in years, company executives said.

The K6 can crunch numbers, animate graphics and play video games slightly faster than Intel's top-of-the-line Pentium Pro, AMD executives claim. It also will sell for at least 25 percent less than Intel's rival chips.

"This is the first time in our corporate history that we will have a contemporaneous product for the mainstream that is equivalent to Intel's mainstream product in performance," said Ben Anixter, AMD vice president of corporate affairs.
By offering a microprocessor that works as well as an Intel chip, AMD will have more chances to land PC manufacturers as customers, Anixter said.

Investors are hoping the same thing. Since AMD demonstrated the chip for the first time to industry executives in November, its stock has more than doubled from about $18. On Tuesday, AMD shares fell $1.875 to $39.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.
AMD could ship between two million to four million K6 chips in 1997, said Tony Massimini, analyst at market researcher Semico Research Corp. in Phoenix.

Based on demand for the new chip, AMD's revenue from microprocessor sales could rise more than three-fold to $1.1 billion in 1997, compared with $340 million in 1996, estimated Mark Edelstone, at brokerage Prudential Securities in New York.
At least one major PC maker is expected to announce plans Wednesday to make machines based on AMD's K6, analysts said.

Intel spokesman Howard High said Intel has not yet had a chance to inspect the K6. While he would not be surprised if the K6 does well on everyday calculations, he said he expects the chip to "fall short" in high-end graphics applications.
